description: From Bengali মফস্বল (môphôsbôl /môphośśôl/, “divided”), from Persian مفصل‎ (mofassal), from Arabic مُفَصَّل‎ (mufaṣṣal), passive participle of فَصَّلَ‎ (faṣṣala, “to divide, classify”).

entries.meaning: (India) Originally, the regions of India outside the three East India Company capitals of Bombay, Calcutta and Madras; hence, parts of a country outside an urban centre; the regions, rural areas.
examples: Such are the means by which the Mofussil, “up-country,” or provincial Anglo-Indian will reach his station or district, and unless he is going to Bombay or Calcutta, which are practically the two entrance doors of the Empire, with Madras for a back door, his first experience of Anglo-Indian life will be of travel; and the land journey will often prove much more trying than the sea-voyage.
